en: Letter from J. T. Hand to Professor Louis L. McInnis written from Bonham, Texas in April 1880 (with notation of April 1884), expressing personal distress over professional injuries and wounded pride while discussing school matters and teaching positions. Hand reflects on his emotional state, requests support from McInnis in the Pilot newspaper to restore his reputation, and mentions salary concerns and increasing school enrollment. The correspondence reveals tensions in nineteenth-century Texas education and the social consequences of professional disputes.

Bonham Texas
April 2 - 1880

Dear Professor
Several causes have combined
to delay a reply to your last good letter -
While I love my friends more than ever
I have lost much of my former cheerful
spirit - feeling that I am at the mercy
of any vulgar mind which may see
fit to taunt me at any time -
I see the Galveston News now & then - from
which I see the world is still moving -
Roberts booms & Grant receptions seem to be
on a "craze" - Well I cant help it -
Wish I could try & practice Dum vivimus vivamus
Let the dead past be forgotten - but like
Poe's Raven injured innocence wounded
pride & disappointed ambition ever & anon
steal upon me, & ask why the change & echo
answers Why!. You remember how I used
to enjoy a hearty laugh - a smile is now
as far as I can go - that not often -

[1880, April 2]

Horace, I think wrote: Ego hos versiculos feci
tulit alter honores - In some small degree
I participate the feeling of the old Roman -
But it makes no difference now with him -
Who bore the honors - So 100 years hence, nothing
I'll reck if they'll let me sleep on in
some little grave where a few friends
may lay me - But it is wrong to burden
a friend with a recital of my injuries -
I'll stop - I see now & then a letter in the
Pilot from "Richard" - He writes a facile
pen & tells the truth - but leaves one
in doubt as to his name and local
habitation - Gen L. goes to Waxahachie -
A good place for that "best mathematician
& clearest teacher, in the South, outside the
University of Va" - What say you?
I hear nothing from the "dead Injuns" -
except now & then a good letter from Pres. G.
He is "toiling on" I suppose you hear from
him often - School matters here not
changed since I wrote you last

[1884, April 2]

I will state to you, in confidence, unless
there is an increase of Salary here I will
look elsewhere - after June - We have had
a steady increase in patronage since Decr.
last - Present enrollment is 450 against
375 - the enrollment when I came here -
Should I go elsewhere, I feel that I need some
moral & professional Support - You noticed
the acquiescence of the press in our decapitation -
Would it embarrass you to give me some
support in the Pilot? Under your own sign
manual or a nom de plume - as you prefer -
I know the indelicacy of this request & am
ashamed to make it - but I feel that I
am "branded" & down & dont see just how
I am to get up - Hope your prospects are good
& your surroundings pleasant -
Your success will ever give me pleasure -
Don't imitate my long silence -

Your friend
[Signature] J. T. Hand
